Award.AbstractNarration:
Technical Description: Two-dimensional nanomaterials have potential for novel electronics. However the materials science of fabricating and merging of different two-dimensional (2D) nanomaterials into a device has not yet been established. This project aims at understanding fundamental materials science problems of 2D-nanomaterial interfaces using atomic-scale surface science characterization techniques. The research consists of three thrust areas: (i) Investigation and tuning of metal- graphene interfaces: Electrical contacts with graphene are important for any device. New strategies are devised on how to disperse metal-atoms on the surface of graphene by utilizing two-dimensional metal-organic frameworks supported on graphene. (ii) Developing methods for synthesizing heterostructures of 2D materials and characterizing their properties: To achieve heterolayers of hexagonal boron nitride (h-BN) on graphene on a wafer-sized scale vapor growth of h-BN on a metal support is combined with graphene formation by carbon segregation from the metal bulk. (iii) Synthesizing and characterizing novel 2D man-made nanomaterials with no structural analogy in bulk materials: Most 2D nanomaterials are based on van-der-Waals bulk materials that can be exfoliated into individual atomic (molecular) sheets. In this project the possibility of synthesizing entirely new materials that do not have any bulk counterparts is explored.

Non-technical Description: This project addresses fundamental materials science issues of graphene and related two-dimensional materials. Growth of various two-dimensional materials and characterization their interfaces are carried out using surface science techniques. Research results from this project will be included in the curriculum of courses on Materials Physics/Surface Science and Solid State Physics taught by the PI. In addition, this project offers graduate projects for two PhD students and research experience for undergraduate students. It also facilitates the continuation of a recently implemented cooperation between researchers at the University of South Florida and the Center for Functional Nanomaterials at the Brookhaven National Laboratory.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Layered materials, i.e. materials with strong covalent bonding in an atomic-plane but weak interaction between planes, hold promise for the fabrication of new functional materials and (opto)electronic devices. One important aspect for this class of materials is that the weak interlayer interaction enables the combination of diverse materials with atomically abrupt interfaces and thus design artificial materials with novel properties. This project focused on the synthesis of single atomic layer materials, their integration with dissimilar materials, and investigations on how the properties of single layers are modified by the formation of interfaces.

The early part of the project focused on the synthesis of graphene by low pressure chemical vapor deposition on metal surfaces in particular nickel. In our studies we demonstrated the successful monolayer growth of graphene on nickel by systematically characterizing the surface phases formed and their dependence on growth temperatures and carbon concentration in the bulk of nickel growth substrate. The result showed that monolayer graphene can be grown on nickel in a narrow temperature regime under low hydrocarbon pressures. Characterization of interfaces between graphene and various other materials were enabled by a transfer process from a metal growth substrate to substrates of interest. Specifically we were interested in the interface formation between graphene and other layered materials. Contrary to the expectations that only weak interlayer interactions exist we found evidence of hybridization of electronic states of the graphene with a MoS2 substrate and thus demonstrated that heterostructures of layered materials can have unique properties that are different than just the sum of the individual components. This idea of modifying the materials properties of layered materials by making artificial heterostructures has been taken up in the second part of this project by investigating the direct growth of one layered material on top of another by molecular beam epitaxy. By comparing the electronic structure of  single layer MoSe2 grown on either MoS2 or graphite substrates we could show that the chalcogen (Se or S) orbitals hybridize and modify the electronic structure of MoSe2 on MoS2, while the electronic structure for MoSe2 on graphite is similar to that expected for free standing monolayers. This result gives further evidence that the properties of heterostructures of 2D materials is sensitively dependent on interlayer interactions. Finally, for the growth of MoSe2 on various substrates we found the formation of a large density of twin-grain boundaries. This observation, led to the study of the properties of these grain boundaries. Grain boundaries in a two dimensional materials are one dimensional structures. In the case of the twin boundaries in MoSe2 they also exhibit metallic behavior. The physics of one dimensional metals is fundamentally different from that in two- or three- dimensions. Thus the discovery of these one dimensional metals in MoSe2 twin grain boundaries allowed us to address fundamental problems in low dimensional condensed matter physics. Among others, we could demonstrate that the electrons in this grain boundary behave in a correlated fashion and we showed evidence for a theoretical behavior that is known as ‘spin-charge’ separation and alludes to the fact that in one-dimensions the two main quantities of an electron, i.e. its spin and charge, behave like they belong to separate (quasi)particles.

This project provided training to 3 graduate students in an exciting, contemporary research field of solid state and materials physics. Two of these graduate students have already successfully defended their PhD theses and the third is scheduled to defend her thesis in fall. All of the students who have worked on this project spent some time at research facilities in Europe and thus had the opportunity to gain international experience. Other international exchanges included hosting students from abroad and the PI spending time in research labs abroad. The findings of the research on the role of interlayer interactions and the synthesis of 2D heterostructure materials has potential ramifications for making applied materials and devices from these novel materials class.
